section1.title: 1. Introduction ‚Äî What is NIRD?
section1.p1: The NIRD approach is an educational movement that aims to help schools adopt a digital environment that is freer, more ethical, and more sustainable.
section1.p2: It brings together teachers, students, technicians, local authorities, and associations to build a digital world truly at the service of education.

section2.title: 2. Why NIRD? ‚Äî Why does it matter?
section2.p1:
Today, many institutions depend heavily on large technology companies. This dependence creates problematic situations:

‚Ä¢ functional hardware becomes unusable due to an update,
‚Ä¢ software licenses weigh heavily on budgets,
‚Ä¢ school data is stored outside Europe,
‚Ä¢ closed ecosystems prevent schools from adapting or repairing their tools.
section2.p2: Faced with these constraints, NIRD proposes another path: regaining power over the digital environment, reducing ecological impact, and developing more autonomous and sustainable practices.

section3.title: 3. The Three Pillars of NIRD
section3.p1: Inclusion: reducing digital inequalities, ensuring access for all, using accessible and free tools.
section3.p2: Responsibility: limiting carbon footprint, consuming fewer digital resources, favoring data-respectful tools.
section3.p3: Durability: extending hardware life, fighting planned obsolescence, encouraging free software and repair.

section4.title: 4. NIRD‚Äôs Main Actions (the 6 activities)
section4.p1: 1. Raising awareness about digital sobriety ‚Äî Educating on energy impact, encouraging reasoned uses: responsible storage, limited streaming, device optimization.
section4.p2: 2. Reuse & Refurbishment ‚Äî Repairing and reusing rather than throwing away: reducing electronic waste and saving resources.
section4.p3: 3. Promoting Linux ‚Äî Extending hardware life, reducing costs, favoring free and secure software.
section4.p4: 4. Pooling free tools ‚Äî Sharing resources, guides, and software via The Forge of Educational Digital Commons.
section4.p5: 5. Supporting eco-responsible transition ‚Äî Technical advice, workshops, practical guides, help for local authorities.
section4.p6: 6. Co-constructing local solutions ‚Äî Creating adapted tools: applications, educational resources, local infrastructures.
